And so basically all sunflowers

And I don't know,
if you guys are going to give me field, as an agriculture pun

Good joke. It's a good pun. Yeah, it's good. So I started studying sunflower genetics
when I was an evolution,

when I was a graduate student. And I was making
low resolution genetic maps

or genome maps of sunflower back
in the late 1980s. So it was kind of doing genomics
before genomics existed, so to speak.

And that was at the point
where the datasets were quite small, right, just several 100 markers.

And so you didn't require huge amounts
of computational power. Of course, with the advent
of high throughput sequencing
in the 2000 it changed everything. Instead of a few 100 markers,

we can now interrogate all 3.6 billion
base pairs of the sunflower genome.

And so genomics became big data. And, of course, that led ultimately
to this collaboration with AWS.

And you could see some
of the wonderful variations in sunflowers there and that's why.

Yeah. Yeah, as we were just saying,
you know, sunflowers are so visually diverse,

you know, you think about like Van Gogh's
sunflowers versus the sunflowers that we think of today,
like what Karen's family has planted.

Can you kind of help us maybe understand
a little bit about some of the differences from then to now?

Yeah. So, you know, what's interesting
is that one of my former postdocs

actually cloned the gene
and characterized the mutation

that was underlying Van Gogh's mutation. It was his lab,
but that is not while he was in my lab.

And it's a mutation in a gene
called CYCLOIDEA.

And what this CYCLOIDEA
does is it's responsible for making the sunflower petal,
it's actually a ray flower.

And the mutation that they found
is actually just upstream or just beside the CYCLOIDEA gene.

And what it does is it causes
this gene to be expressed not just on the edge of a sunflower head,

but throughout the sunflower. And so you get those ray flowers
or petals growing everywhere.

And that gives you
the Van Gogh sunflower, and sometimes
also called in the sunflower community,
it's called a double-flower mutation. It's quite common.

And also in the trade, it's sometimes referred
to as the Teddy Bear sunflower, because of the, sort of,
fuzzy nature of the flowers.

So in addition to Van Gogh's sunflower
or Teddy Bear sunflower, there are two kinds of commercial sunflowers
that are primarily grown.

One of them is the one that Karen
was referring to in Manitoba, in particular. They're typically confection sunflowers grown
and these are the ones

with the large seeds
and the white stripe down the seed that you see in a grocery store. And that's ones that you eat.

The other main type of sunflower
are the oil seed sunflowers. So these have smaller black seeds.

And both confectionery and oil sunflowers,
when you see them in the field, they actually are fairly short. They're typically three to five feet tall.

And this is quite different
from the giant sunflowers that you see growing in your backyard.

And but these giant sunflowers
are also sometimes grown commercially for biomass or biogas.
And in Germany, for example, we often see these giant sunflowers

grown here biogas plants. And the reason is, is that Germans prefer
to see sunflowers rather than maize,

which is typically used
in the biogas facility. That makes a lot of sense.

And that amount of complexity
and you think about that genome itself, I'm really curious,

how do you use the underlying technologies like AWS has to enable
the massive amount of genomic analysis

in order to understand
the different types of the sunflowers?
So our main problem before we push
this toward AWS was that it simply took us too long to analyze our data.

The datasets kept on getting bigger
and bigger, and the one that we put
on AWS is truly massive.

And so it was taking us a year or so to run certain analyses,
you know, which is too long.

So then we turn to the cloud, which allowed us to complete our analyses
in a more reasonable amount of time.

We're able to massively parallelize
the analyses. And JS will talk about that a little bit. And also, another good thing
about the open repository

on AWS was that it gave us a place
to store data
in the same place that it could also be used. And that's a huge, time component is just transferring the data
from one storage component to another. Yeah.

That's right. One fundamental shift that the cloud allows
is that you don't really have to scrounge

for resources the way you would normally
have to do it in a university setting. We have to, you know,
book a few servers on the compute cluster.

In the cloud, you can do one machine
running for 1,000 hours, but that's roughly
the same cost as 1,000 machines
for an hour or 2,000 for half an hour. So that's sort of the big difference there.

And another thing that's a bit more subtle
about the cloud is that it lets you put labels
and tags on about just any piece

of data that you generate. So anything you compute for an hour,
you can give it a URL, you can go visit it,
you can share it with people very easily.

And we, as part of the work
in the Rieseberg Lab, we built a framework on AWS
that lets you, it's called Bunnies.

It allows you to reproducibly
compute large scale genomics experiments. So it's a pipeline framework.

Okay. I've got to ask,
why is your pipeline called Bunnies?

Yeah, I know. We use it for sunflowers, but it's called bunnies
because they reproduce a lot.
So it was all acts on reproducibility. So there's a...

Loren kind of briefly touched
base on this, which is that in academia
there's a lot of rotation between students and projects.

And over the years, you end up reusing
some of the results from previous, former students
or former researchers or other teams
even in other universities. And it's very challenging to know exactly

all the steps that were involved
in producing a large dataset. You spend, you know, thousands,
and thousands, and thousands of dollars
into sequencing, aligning,
you know, variant calling your dataset, and you have to know how it was generated,

what software was used. And so that framework essentially
is a way to capture provenance,

every piece of
data that is generated, you can go from there and see
what all the raw inputs

were used to generate it. And so if you spot a problem
later on in your pipeline,

you can kind of go back and see all the files
that were affected by this change.

Very cool. You know, for us it's... Bunnies has been really useful,
not just in capturing that sort of information about exactly
how it was done.

But one of the things that we find
is that we're constantly producing new and better reference genomes
and new pangenomes that we use,

and then we want to take all of our data
and reanalyze it again. And it just happens repeatedly.

And so having a pipeline like Bunnies
makes all of this much more reproducible

and much easier going forward. That was great insight about
how you guys kind of set the systems

up to do that analysis. But after you've kind of now started
looking at the data

and ingesting it
and doing computation on it, what kind of insights
from the sequencing projects
kind of stuck with you the most? I think the one big thing is scale.

Essentially, for a lot of the analyses
that we had to do in the Rieseberg Lab,

the datasets grow over time. And the more data you include
in your analysis, the more sort of statistical confidence
you gain in your results,

the more resolution you have. And it comes at a point
where the compute time you need to spend

to analyze these data, it grows exponentially
with the amount of data you have.

You realize, you know, sooner or later
that the fixed set of resources that you have in your university
or your lab or just won't cut it,

or you'll have to exponentially
wait longer to get the results. And so I think the cloud
is really where it shines,

where you can practice, can sort of assume
you have as much compute power
as you possibly could want.
The other place where, again, scale plays a role is that if you are to fit,

it really is the only place
where you can imagine having, you know, every single plant genome
fit inside one system.

So it's something that's referred
to as the pangenome having a reference that encompasses
all the possible variations

in the species through across species. And, you know, I think
that's where the cloud really
can come in as a hero in the story. Let's get to know.

So let's talk a little bit more,
Dr. Rieseberg. Sunflowers can really kind of grow
in some harsh conditions.

Can you kind of walk us through some of? I think, we've got a visual here
that will talk through. Yeah, certainly.

So part of our interest in sunflowers
is that they're often found

in extreme habitats. And they're also cross compatible
with domesticated sunflowers. So you can basically mine genes
from these wild extremophile species to breed more environmental resilient

or more climate adapted sunflowers. And so for me, one of the big discoveries
from this AWS OpenProject

that we did with JS
was that we found that the genes... We discovered many of the genes
that were actually underlying

these adaptations
to these extreme environments, so they can be directly targeted
by breeders.

But what was both interesting
and challenging, it is that many of these
were actually inherited

as non-recombining blocks of genes or as what we call in the literature,
supergenes.

And in most cases, these supergenes
were formed by large inversions

or large other structural rearrangements
or structural variants. And so it's interesting
because these supergenes

could be employed by sunflower breeders
to sort of more rapidly adapt sunflowers to extreme conditions
or to various stressful conditions.

But they also represent
an important challenge to sunflower breeding, not just to us in terms of analyzing them,
but also to sunflower breeders,

because these blocks of genes not only contain the genes that the breeders
want that might make,

for example,
a sunflower more drought tolerant, more tolerant to low-nutrient conditions,

but they also contain genes
that the breeders don't want, but they're inherited as a box.

So it's going to be very difficult
for them to be sort of those blocks to be tease the part
and to pull up the individual gene.

So it's both the interesting finding,
but also a challenge.

So the next question is for Erin. The Registry of Open Data on AWS
contains the genome

from the University of British Columbia
in terms of what they've contributed in terms of the sunflower dataset.

It's updated twice a year,
it's available in an S3 bucket. Could you tell us why the Registry
of Open Data on AWS exists

for these types of genomics projects? And what that looks like
for others to use it?
I sure can. And as I said earlier, we on the Open Data team really believe

in democratizing data access
in the cloud. And I think that for the life sciences
in genomics, in particular,

where you have groups
working on similar projects and really accessing
the same sources of public data.

This program and registry
is just so important, right? So we develop the Registry
of Open Data or as we affectionately

call it RODA to be a catalog
of this publicly accessible data on AWS,

all stored in Amazon S3. So these data sets are maintained
by data providers
who come from all over the AWS ecosystem. And that includes academia, government,
nonprofit organizations, startups, and biotech pharma, larger corporations.

And along with information
on where and how you can access the data, as Karen said that these all live
in public S3 buckets,

and so you can actually
access these right out of S3. RODA is going to allow the community
to curate and provide tutorials,

uses it's examples,
publications relevant to the data, and that's the data provider
and the data users.

So basically, we're helping data users
and data providers form an ecosystem.

We call it a community of practice
or the efforts of one person, regardless of if they're making
the data or they're using the data,
it's gonna get affect the whole community. Okay.

So then, Dr. Rieseberg, what was some of your hope for how this contributed dataset
is being used?

Are they're like global collaborations,
public, private use, you know, what's also the benefit
to the Rieseberg Lab

for contributing to some of this data? Yeah. So our data is used,
we expect it to be used globally

and certainly has been in the past. Many of the public
and private breeding programs have obtained germplasm from us
that contains alleles from or genes
to do a genomic based research. And in this particular dataset on AWS,

we think it will be most useful
for creating sort of environmentally resilient sunflowers
or climate adapted sunflowers,

because we've actually identified
genomic regions or individual genes
that we know, for example,

lead to greater heat tolerance
or allow greater tolerance and so forth.

So we imagined that
those will be targeted first. And but also any large dataset,

like those contains huge claims enormous amounts
of variation.

And companies are very interested,
for example, in disease resistance. So I'm sure they'll also target
the dataset to search

for potential disease resistance targets
as well. And in terms of our benefits, you know,

we work closely with a lot
of both public and private breeders, and we have many projects with them,
and so we benefit from their success.

And we also... The AWS provides a very nice way
to store data for free,

because that's one of the real challenges
we have is actually keeping these large amounts
of data and storing them

and keeping them in a way
that they're available for us to use.

Phfan1987,

you know, we actually don't know

is probably going to be
about twice the size of, sort of,
a single genome. But if you add in all the repeated elements

if it's 10 times the size

We don't know for sure yet though. Cool. Second question we got here

- That makes sense.

at eating local food in crop banks.
Yeah, so...
Let's see. Yeah, so... Oh. I guess I was supposed to wait.

No, that's no problem. Yeah, so can you just tell

Yeah. So this was something that came out
of a meeting that one of my graduate students
and I organized about a decade ago.

We were interested in... We got together a group of people
who are working on the genomics

of crop wild relatives
with the interest of, sort of, trying to tap the diversity
of wild species in crop breeding.
And one of the sort of main conclusion

that came out of this meeting, the main challenge we realized
was that we needed an open database

to catalogue all of the genomic
and phenotypic diversity found in the world seed banks.

This is where all germplasm
from crops and their wild relatives are being maintained.

And initially,
at that meeting we were super ambitious, we were thinking
that we should actually sequence

them all ourselves,
you know, form a consortium to do it. And then we became a little less,

sort of, more realistic, I suppose. And we did publish a paper
in nature, sort of,

outlining what we thought should be done,
which was basically to make a database.

And this effort was led
by Susan McCouch at Cornell University. She was one of the participants
that helped organize

that original meeting. And the DivSeek International, it's now a legal entity
in Canada led by Susan,

and it focuses
on developing and guiding standards that people should use in gathering
and sharing information

and in the development of databases. Awesome. And I do have to call out Cornell,
I am a three-time Cornell alumni.

My first degree was from the College
of Agriculture and Life Sciences. So, you know, heart beat a little faster,
happiness there.

But now with my role
on the Open Data team, one thing that you did mention,
Loren, was, you know,

gold standards for how people
should be developing databases with the objective of sharing data.

And what I see personally
with a lot of my data users is the struggle to access
and then harmonize data

across different databases
coming from different sources. What strategy did you take to harmonize
the datasets that are compiled in DivSeek?

Well, yeah, I mean,
this is the perennial challenge, right? This is why we thought there
should be a single database

that everything was on it,
but it turns out people aren't. They want their data in their own thing.
And so what we focused on really was to make sure

that the different databases
can talk to each other. And so that's the key thing. And also, we ask that our members ascribe

to the fair principles, this is that makes information findable,
accessible, interoperable,

which is the most difficult thing
and reusable. And we also, sort of, provide, I guess,
soft moral pressure to for those and encouragement

for those who are not making their data
easily usable and accessible by others. There are a lot of different personalities
in the field.

And some people are very comfortable
with sharing everything, and others really aren't.

And that's what we see
in daily life as well. So it's no different in genomics. All right, definitely agree.

And this isn't really agriculture,
even genomic specific, but do you have any words
of advice for researchers

out there who are trying
to aggregate and reuse data?

I do have a few things to say
about that on the technology side of things, which is that especially
in terms of aggregation,

putting things in the same bucket,
in the same basket. Technology is making things easier
for sharing and making things public

and giving, you know,
accessible URLs to things. Other than that when you have your data
in your data store,

your data lake, you know,
the other thing you need to do is, you know, tagging the data properly. If it's not tagged, annotated,

no one is going to use it with very high,
you know, confidence.
And so this can go down to like defining an ontology for your data,

like what exactly
do you mean by seed size? You know, how do you measure your seeds?

Seed color,
making sure everybody's using the same, you know, palettes.

Defining if you align something
or if you do variant calling, and finding what references
you've been using

to perform these computations. And so figuring out
when you have access to data,

whether you can use it does
also require that the methodology that you used
in your experiment and you...

both what happens in the wet lab
and what happens in computer, you know, you need to include
the program versions that you used,

what parameters you used. And, you know, you need
to have potentially like a search,

make it data searchable
or have an index to figure out, access things quickly.

Yeah, that's what I'd say
on the technology side. Yeah. So...
Yeah, I would agree with JS, that metadata submission is super important.

In seed banks
they call this passport data. And this provides information
about any individual seeds

and where they came from,
what the environment was like, and so forth. And often they have phenotypic information
about the seeds and so forth.

And that's really, really critical. A goal that we have at DivSeek,
and so forth,

is to actually link genomic data
to the physical germplasm,

everything with the DOI,
digital object identifier. And so that any type of genomic data
can go back to the actual seed accessions
that operator can use and can order from the seed banks.

That is really interesting. Especially, you know,
thinking about the storage constraints and then having that passport data lineage,

it's really interesting to think about
how that can be used in genomics. But, Matt,
let's bring it back to the field.

All right, all right. Our last few minutes, so why don't we touch on what many considered
to be the genomic revolution,

and which warranted, I think, the Nobel Prize in Chemistry
this year as well, genome editing.
